title: What is the function of gill filaments in fish gills? - Quora

response.answer_text: Mr. Crowder’s explication is more than adequate to the issue and I see no reason to respond further. In a nutshell, a fish’s gill filaments act much like the alveoli in our own lungs, providing lots of surface area for the transfer of gases (oxygen in, carbon dioxide out), with the added purpose of also allowing the excretion of certain waste products (such as ammonia) which may have built up in/been collected by the blood.

They are thin-walled, finely divided elements of the gill designed to provide as much surface area as possible through which to exchange oxygen and carbon dioxide. Just one more aspect of fish being “fearfully and wonderfully made.”
